user_location: West Down, Northern Ireland, Northern Ireland
review_blob:
Pint (draught) from the Gall Bog Bar near Banbridge, County Down. 
Probably one of the lightest mainstream lagers available in Ireland, fairly small frothy head. Tastes as light as it looks, a bit of bitterness but not very much of anything else, slightly malty. Available on tap, in bottles and in cans in Northern Ireland - and occasionally as Harp Ice Cold, which Id probably recommend if you insist on drinking Harp.
Drinkable but excessively bland, on the lower side of average.

user_location: West Down, Northern Ireland, Northern Ireland
review_blob:
This one is available in a handful of decent off licences in Belfast and Dublin - picked a bottle up in Molloys at Nutgrove in Dublin 14. 
Hoppy aroma and good solid flavour although by no means unpleasant - flavour certainly fruity, Id say its most like bananas, so slightly sweet although not sickeningly so. Not much bitterness either. Rather potent but very quaffable.

user_location: West Down, Northern Ireland, Northern Ireland
review_blob:
Cask at The Victoria, Durham city (its one of the permanent ales there), also sampled from ten litre polypin purchased directly from brewery on farm near Heddon-on-the-Wall, Northumberland. 
Light colour, taste is grassy with a bit of citrus. In my experience, always a consistent beer. Refreshing and light.

user_location: West Down, Northern Ireland, Northern Ireland
review_blob: Purchased from an independent retailer in Lurgan, County Armagh. Three litre bottle, a tad awkward to handle. Very light colour for a cider, mild carbonation. Doesnt have the initial scent of a cider. Taste is rather acidic and dry, which delivers a manufactured and slightly bitter flavour.
